name: Perseus
subtitle: Slayer of Medusa, Founder of Mycenae
description: Perseus stands among the greatest heroes of Greek mythology, the first of the great Hellenic monster-slayers and founder of the Perseid dynasty. Born of Zeus (who visited Danae as a shower of golden rain) and the mortal princess Danae of Argos, Perseus was cast into the sea with his mother in a wooden chest by her father Acrisius, who feared an oracle that his grandson would kill him. Rescued on the island of Seriphos, Perseus grew to manhood and was sent on what seemed an impossible quest: to bring back the head of the Gorgon Medusa, whose gaze turned all who looked upon her to stone. With divine gifts from the godsâ€”winged sandals, a cap of invisibility, the curved sword harpe, and a magic bagâ€”he accomplished the impossible, also rescuing the Ethiopian princess Andromeda from a sea monster and founding the great city of Mycenae.

birthNarrative: King Acrisius of Argos, warned by an oracle that his daughter's son would kill him, imprisoned Danae in a bronze underground chamber. Zeus entered as a shower of golden rain, and she conceived Perseus. When Acrisius discovered the child, he set mother and son adrift in a wooden chest. They washed ashore on Seriphos, where the fisherman Dictys rescued them.

keyMyths.title: Quest for Medusa's Head
keyMyths.description: King Polydectes, desiring Danae and wanting Perseus gone, sent him to fetch the head of Medusaâ€”the only mortal Gorgon, whose serpent-haired visage turned viewers to stone. Athena and Hermes guided Perseus to the Graeae (three sisters sharing one eye and tooth), who revealed the location of the Nymphs who possessed the magic items he needed. Flying to the western edge of the world, Perseus found the Gorgons sleeping. Using Athena's polished shield as a mirror to avoid Medusa's direct gaze, he decapitated her with the harpe. From her neck sprang Pegasus and Chrysaor.

keyMyths.title: Rescue of Andromeda
keyMyths.description: Returning from his quest, Perseus saw the Ethiopian princess Andromeda chained to a rock as sacrifice to a sea monster (Cetus), punishment for her mother Cassiopeia's boast that she was more beautiful than the Nereids. Perseus bargained with King Cepheus for Andromeda's hand, then either slew the monster with his sword or petrified it with Medusa's head. When Andromeda's former betrothed Phineus attacked at the wedding feast, Perseus turned him and his followers to stone.

keyMyths.title: Return to Seriphos
keyMyths.description: Perseus returned to find his mother Danae had taken refuge from Polydectes at an altar. He entered the king's hall, announced himself as the bearer of Medusa's head, and when Polydectes and his courtiers expressed disbelief, displayed the head and turned them all to stone. He gave the throne to the good fisherman Dictys.

keyMyths.title: Accidental Killing of Acrisius
keyMyths.description: Perseus returned to Argos to reconcile with his grandfather Acrisius, who fled to Larissa. At funeral games there, Perseus threw a discus that was carried by the wind and struck Acrisius, killing himâ€”thus fulfilling the oracle. Unwilling to inherit the kingdom of a man he had killed, Perseus exchanged Argos for Tiryns and later founded Mycenae.

comparativeNotes.nearEastern: The monster-rescue motif appears in multiple Near Eastern myths; Andromeda's Ethiopian setting suggests possible Egyptian connections
comparativeNotes.folklore: The 'princess and dragon' tale type (AT 300) appears worldwide, with Perseus as its Greek exemplar
comparativeNotes.christian: The monster-slayer rescuing a maiden prefigures St. George and the Dragon

christologicalParallels.overview: Perseus, as the premier Greek monster-slayer and rescuer of the innocent, presents significant typological parallels that Christian interpreters have long recognized.
christologicalParallels.miracleBirth: Perseus's miraculous conceptionâ€”Zeus visiting Danae as golden light penetrating her prisonâ€”parallels the divine overshadowing of Mary. Both heroes have divine fathers and human mothers, born in circumstances that defy natural law.
christologicalParallels.castOutAndPreserved: Like Moses in his basket and Christ fleeing to Egypt, the infant Perseus is cast out by a fearful king yet divinely preserved through floating on waters.
christologicalParallels.serpentSlayer: Medusa, with her serpentine hair and death-dealing power, embodies evil. Perseus's decapitation of this serpent-creature echoes Genesis 3:15â€”the seed of the woman crushing the serpent's head. Christ's victory over Satan follows this pattern.
christologicalParallels.rescuerOfTheInnocent: Perseus saves Andromeda from the sea monster, an innocent victim bound to suffer for others' sins (her mother's pride). This prefigures Christ rescuing humanity, chained to sin, from the power of death and evil.
christologicalParallels.conquerorOfDeath: Medusa's gaze brings death; her severed head continues to petrify. Perseus masters this death-bringing power, using it against evil. Christ similarly conquers death, transforming it into a weapon against evil itself.
christologicalParallels.virginMotherParallel: Danae, imprisoned and seemingly unable to bear children, conceives by divine visitation. Early Christians noted this parallel to Mary's virginal conception, though distinguishing the modes of divine action.

patristics.clement: Clement of Alexandria in Protrepticus discusses how the pagan stories of divine heroes prepared Greek minds to receive the true Divine Hero.
patristics.fulgentius: The 5th-century Christian writer Fulgentius allegorized Perseus's myth, interpreting Medusa as worldly terror conquered by divine wisdom.
patristics.medievalExegesis: Medieval mythographers frequently read Perseus as a type of Christ conquering evil, particularly in the Ovide moralisÃ© tradition.

Perseus rules an earthly kingdom; Christ's kingdom is eternal
Perseus accidentally kills his grandfather (fate); Christ willingly dies for humanity (love)

sources: Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 2.4.1-4 (1st-2nd century CE): The most complete ancient account of Perseus's myth.
Ovid, Metamorphoses 4.604-5.249 (8 CE): Vivid Roman retelling of Medusa, Andromeda, and the wedding battle.
Pindar, Pythian Ode 10, 12 (5th century BCE): Celebrates Perseus's victory and Athena's invention of the flute.
Hesiod, Theogony 270-281 & Shield of Heracles (c. 700 BCE): Early references to Perseus and the Gorgons.
Pausanias, Description of Greece (2nd century CE): Records cult sites at Argos, Mycenae, and Seriphos.
Pherecydes of Athens (5th century BCE): Early prose account of the myth (fragmentary).
Fulgentius, Mythologiae 1.21 (5th century CE): Christian allegorical interpretation.
